citation.article-title: Isolation and characterization of a thermophilic marine methanogenic bacterium: Methanogenium thermophilicum sp.

p.s: Description of Methanogenium thermophilicum sp. nov.
Methanogenium thermophilicum sp. nov. (ther.mo.phil'.i.cum; Gr. n. therme, heat; Gr. adj. philicum, loving; M.L. adj. thermophilicum, heat loving.)
We propose that this new thermophilic marine methanogenic bacterium be placed in the family Methanomicrobiaceae in the genus Methanogenium.

The microbe belongs in this genus because its cells are gram-negative, irregular coccoids which occur singly or in pairs, it is sensitive to 1% sodium dodecyl sulfate, its cell walls become disassociated in older cultures, and it possesses internal membrane components.

It also resembles the members of the genus in that it has a high G+C base ratio, it utilizes only formate or hydrogen and carbon dioxide as growth substrates and for methane formation, and it has a requirement for sodium chloride.
The new isolate is similar to Methanogenium cariaci in its optimum pH for growth and to Methanogenium marisnigri in its G+C base ratio and its Trypticase requirement.

It differs from M. cariaci and M . marisnigri in its optimum growth temperature (55°C) and by its lack of flagella. (Although M. cariaci and M. marisnigri possess flagella, the flagella appear to be nonfunctional.)
Recent immunological fingerprint data (E.
C . dehlacario, personal communication) obtained by the indirect immunofluorescence technique show the new isolate to react only with M. cariaci, M. marisnigri, and Methanomicrobium mobile.
Cells are gram-negative, irregular cocci which occur singly or in pairs, with an average diameter of 1.0 to 1.3 μm; spores are not formed.
Electron micrographs reveal occasional internal membrane components.
Colonies in agar tubes are beige and circular with entire edges.
Either formate or hydrogen and carbon dioxide can serve as a growth substrate.
Neither growth nor methane production was detected within 2 weeks when the H electron donor was replaced by ethanol, methanol, acetate, propionate, or pyruvate.
The organism requires Trypticase and a trace vitamin solution.
The temperature for optimum growth is 55°C.
The pH for optimum growth is 7.0.
The sodium ion concentration for optimum growth of 0.25 M.
The DNA base composition is 59 mol% G+C.
Isolated from sediment underlying the high temperature effluent channel of the Crystal River Nuclear Power Plant, Florida Power Company, Crystal River, Fla.
Type strain: CR-1 (= ATCC 33837 = DSM 2373).
The description of the type strain is the same as that given above for the species.
